description: From Middle English rubriche, rubrike, from Old French rubrique, from Latin rūbrīca (“red ochre”), the substance used to make red letters, from ruber (“red”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁rewdʰ-.

adjectives.description: rubric (comparative more rubric, superlative most rubric)

entries.meaning: Coloured or marked with red; placed in rubrics.
Of or relating to the rubric or rubrics; rubrical.
A heading in a book highlighted in red.
A title of a category or a class.
examples: That would fall under the rubric of things we can ignore for now.

entries.meaning: (Christianity) The directions for a religious service, formerly printed in red letters.
examples: All the clergy in England solemnly pledge themselves to observe the rubrics.

entries.meaning: An established rule or custom; a guideline.
examples: Nay, as a duty, it had no place or rubric in human conceptions before Christianity.

entries.meaning: (education) A set of scoring criteria for evaluating student work and for giving feedback.

verbs.description: rubric (third-person singular simple present rubrics, present participle rubricking, simple past and past participle rubricked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adorn with red; to redden.
To organise or classify into rubrics
